html body div div div main article header h1 span
content: Bill Cosby Sentencing: What to Expect on Decision Day

tag: html body div div div main article header figure div span
html body div div div main article header figure figcaption span
content: Bill Cosby leaves the first day of his sentencing hearing at the Montgomery County Courthouse in Norristown, Pa.

tag: html body div div div main article header figure figcaption span span
html body div div div main article header figure figcaption span span span
html body div div div main article header figure figcaption span span span
html body div div div main article header div div div div p span
html body div div div main article header div div div div p a span
html body div div div main article header div div ul li time span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: • Bill Cosby will be sentenced Tuesday for

tag: html body div div div main article div div p a span
content: drugging and sexually assaulting Andrea Constand

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: at his home near Philadelphia 14 years ago. Prosecutors have asked that he be sentenced to the maximum: 10 years in prison.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: • Mr. Cosby will be given an opportunity to speak to the court before the sentence is handed down. It’s not clear whether he will, and it’s almost certain that he won’t express remorse because he plans on appealing his conviction.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
html body div div div main article div div p a span
content: He is likely to be incarcerated

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: , experts say, though it is unclear for how long.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p a span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: had asked for a sentence of house arrest.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: • Still to be decided: whether Mr. Cosby should be classified as a “sexually violent predator,” a finding under Pennsylvania law that could lead to a sentence at the higher end of the range.

tag: html body div div div main article div div h2 span
content: A psychologist is expected to say Mr. Cosby is no predator

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — Bill Cosby will be sentenced here Tuesday after testimony by a psychologist for the defense, who is expected to say that the entertainer is not a sexually violent predator.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: The expert is likely to contradict a psychologist representing Pennsylvania’s Sexual Offenders Assessment Board who testified Monday, the first day of Mr. Cosby’s sentencing hearing, that he had demonstrated a lifetime interest in sex with nonconsenting women, which indicated a personality disorder or other abnormality.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: The determination of whether a defendant is a sexually violent predator can be a factor in sentencing and in the conditions imposed both in prison and afterward.

tag: html body div div div main article figure div span
html body div div div main article figure figcaption span
content: Journalists converge before sunrise Monday on the site of Mr. Cosby’s sentencing hearing, the Montgomery County Courthouse.

tag: html body div div div main article figure figcaption span span
html body div div div main article figure figcaption span span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Mr. Cosby’s lawyer, Joseph P. Green, argued Monday that Mr. Cosby’s age, 81, and the fact he is legally blind, meant he was no risk, especially since there have been no new allegations of sexual abuse leveled against him since 2004.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: “How’s he going to meet these people?” Mr. Green said. “There is no reasonable prospect that an 81-year-old blind man is likely to reoffend.”

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: But the psychologist for the state panel, Kristen F. Dudley, said she did not believe the disorder had dissipated with age. “It is possible that he has already met someone who could be a future victim,” she said.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: The final decision rests with Judge Steven T. O’Neill, who is presiding over the hearing.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Once Judge O’Neill has made his ruling on the predator question, which is expected midmorning Tuesday, he will proceed with sentencing, which could lead, later in the day, to one of the world’s best-known entertainers entering a prison cell.

tag: html body div div div main article div div h2 span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Mr. Cosby was convicted in April of drugging and assaulting Andrea Constand, a former Temple University employee to whom he had been a mentor.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Ms. Constand spoke in court on Monday, along with her mother, father and sister.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p a span
html body div div div main article div div p span
html body div div div main article div div p a span
content: The jury heard me, Mr. Cosby heard me and now all I am asking for is justice as the court sees fit.”

tag: html body div div div main article figure div span
html body div div div main article figure figcaption span
content: Andrea Constand, the victim of sexual assault by Mr. Cosby, said Monday she was asking for "justice as the court sees fit."

tag: html body div div div main article figure figcaption span span
html body div div div main article figure figcaption span span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: But the most dramatic moment of the hearing may be yet to come if Mr. Cosby finally speaks at length to the many accusations that have been leveled against him. Though he has denied sexually abusing any of the women who have accused him, he has not addressed the matter in a sustained way.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Most experts say they do not anticipate that Mr. Cosby will express remorse because his team has already announced his plan to appeal his conviction. Nevertheless, Judge O’Neill encouraged him to speak.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: “I hope that if he so chooses he will get the last word,” Judge O’Neill said.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: At least seven women who have accused Mr. Cosby of similar acts of sexual abuse were in the courtroom Monday to watch the sentencing, including three who testified at the trial in April. Expect many of them to return on Tuesday.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: But Mrs. Cosby? She was absent Monday. Will she be there Tuesday?

tag: html body div div div main article div div h2 span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Mr. Cosby had faced a maximum 30-year prison term: 10 years for each of three counts of aggravated indecent assault he was convicted of.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: But Judge O’Neill chose on Monday to merge the counts into one, as is allowed when they stem from the same event. In this case, they originated with an encounter in January 2004 when,

tag: html body div div div main article div div p a span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: , Mr. Cosby sexually assaulted her after giving her pills that made her drift in and out of consciousness.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
html body div div div main article div div p a span
html body div div div main article div div p span
content: that recommend, but do not mandate, appropriate sentence ranges. Those guidelines, which take into account any previous criminal record (Mr. Cosby has none), the seriousness of the offense, and mitigating and aggravating factors, suggest a range of about 10 months to four years, But Judge O’Neill has great leeway, and prosecutors on Monday asked him to sentence Mr. Cosby to a maximum five-to-10-year term.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Kevin R. Steele, the Montgomery County District Attorney, said the judge should use the sentencing to send a wider message.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: “The bottom line, your honor, is nobody’s above the law,” said Mr. Steele. “Others in a similar situation need to understand that.”

tag: html body div div div main article div div h2 span
content: Will he remain free on appeal?

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: Mr. Cosby’s lawyers have filed several motions suggesting that they will pursue an appeal that challenges the judge’s rulings and even the judge’s personal integrity.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: A key question for Tuesday will be whether Mr. Cosby is allowed to remain out on bond during the appeal process, which could take years.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: His lawyers will argue that he is not a flight risk, and that he is not likely to commit another crime.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: But if Judge O’Neill were to permit him to stay at home, the judge would surely face bitter criticism from the many female accusers eager for closure this week.

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: On Monday, Mr. Green argued in favor of house arrest, saying Mr. Cosby is a danger to no one and that the court must be careful not to allow public opinion to affect its decision making. “In this case we rely on you to make sure that that public advocacy doesn’t affect the application of the rule of law,” he said, adding later, “It’s your obligation to make sure that the sentencing decision is not affected by all that noise.”

tag: html body div div div main article div div p span
content: But prosecutors rejected defense arguments that Mr. Cosby would be victimized in a prison because of his age and his blindness, and said that state correctional authorities have experience dealing with inmates Mr. Cosby’s age and older.

tag: html body div div div main article div header h3 span
html body div div div main article div div a div div div div h2 span
